g.text: Analyses of the dynamics of the low carbon transition suggest that it does not
occur by itself and that it
signal credible enough in the perception of market players and investors
. Credibility could require a policy commitment device
ed to be large enough (analogous to the “whatever it takes” statement by the
In principle, public investments in low carbon infrastructures (or private
regulation could provide credible signals if their magnitude and time horizon are appropriate (past
experiences with FiTs models across countries provide useful lessons).
Entering 2020, the world already faced large macroeconomic headwinds to meeting the climate finance
ted action. While an understanding of the
approach to raising climate finances analysed in the later parts of this Chapter remains important,
drivers of finance remain crucial in the near
term finance financial flows in aggregate often show strong empirically observed cycles over time,
especially in terms of macroeconomic and financial cycles. By
, we mean here the likely cycle
over the next five to ten years (2020
real business cycles (output, investment and consumption), with periodic asymmetric downside impacts
(Gertler and Kiyotaki 2010; Borio 2014; Jordà et al. 2017; Borio et al. 2018)
movements (asset prices, credit growth, interest rates, leverage, risk factors,
consequences for all types of financial flows such as equity, bond and banking credit markets, which in
turn are likely to impact climate finance flows to all sub
volatility in more risky and more leveraged regions). This is in contrast to
climate finance and policies. The upward trends of the cycles
tend to favour speculative bubbles like
real estates at the expenses of investment in production and infrastructures whereas the asymmetric
downsides raise uncertainty and risks for longer
term investments on newer climate technologies, and
creditworthy countries, and away from cross
this respect, the impact of financial
regulation is unclear. On the one hand, it could be argued that the tighter bank regulations under Basel
III, combined with an economic environment with higher uncertainty and flatter yield curve, can push
trench from climate finance projects (Blended Finance Taskforce, 2018a), since banks tend
to limit loan maturity to 5 or 8 years, while infrastructure projects typically require the amortisation of
. On the other hand, other studies report that stricter capital
requirements are not a driving factor for moving away from sustainability projects
Four key aspects of the global macroeconomy, each slightly different, pointed in a cascading fashion
towards a deteriorating environment for stepped
up climate financing over the next crucial decade
19. The argument is often made that there is enough climate
financing available if the right projects and enabling policy actions (‘bankable projects’) present
. The attention to ‘bankability’ does not however address
at the sectoral and microeconomic level were nevertheless happening in specific
such as solar energy financing and labelled green bonds (although how much of such labelled financing
is incremental to unlabelled financing that might have happened anyway remains uncertain)
